page.title: List of recurring The Simpsons characters

rev.comment: This is not vandalism. Please see [[WP:NFC#Unacceptable_images]]. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 2: Line 2:
== Agnes Skinner ==
== Agnes Skinner ==
â
[[Image:simp agnes.gif|left|100 px|thumb|Agnes Skinner]]
 
'''Agnes Skinner''' (voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]] and once by [[Dan Castellaneta]]) is an elderly widow and the adopted mother of [[Seymour Skinner|Principal Seymour Skinner]]. She first appeared in "[[The Crepes of Wrath]]". She is harshly controlling of Seymour, who spends more time with her than with his old girlfriend, [[Edna Krabappel]]. Her voice is similar to [[Mom (Futurama)| Mom]] from Futurama, who is also voiced by Tress MacNeille.
'''Agnes Skinner''' (voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]] and once by [[Dan Castellaneta]]) is an elderly widow and the adopted mother of [[Seymour Skinner|Principal Seymour Skinner]]. She first appeared in "[[The Crepes of Wrath]]". She is harshly controlling of Seymour, who spends more time with her than with his old girlfriend, [[Edna Krabappel]]. Her voice is similar to [[Mom (Futurama)| Mom]] from Futurama, who is also voiced by Tress MacNeille.
Line 18: Line 17:
==Artie Ziff==
==Artie Ziff==
â   â
[[Image:Artie Ziff.jpg|thumb|170px|left|Artie Ziff]]
 
'''Artie Ziff''', voiced by [[Jon Lovitz]] and occasionally by [[Dan Castellaneta]], was first seen as [[Marge Simpson]]âs high school prom date with âbusy handsâ in â[[The Way We Was]]â. In â[[Half-Decent Proposal]]â he was revealed to have become a nerdy, self-centered, and pretentious software billionaire, becoming the fifth richest man in the country. His wealth came from a device that transforms [[modem]] noise into [[easy listening|easy listening music]], Hence the saying "Hey computer geek, you'll be connected in no-time.". He claims that he would offer a small fortune for a weekend with his childhood love, Marge, in a parody of the movie ''[[Indecent Proposal]]''.
'''Artie Ziff''', voiced by [[Jon Lovitz]] and occasionally by [[Dan Castellaneta]], was first seen as [[Marge Simpson]]âs high school prom date with âbusy handsâ in â[[The Way We Was]]â. In â[[Half-Decent Proposal]]â he was revealed to have become a nerdy, self-centered, and pretentious software billionaire, becoming the fifth richest man in the country. His wealth came from a device that transforms [[modem]] noise into [[easy listening|easy listening music]], Hence the saying "Hey computer geek, you'll be connected in no-time.". He claims that he would offer a small fortune for a weekend with his childhood love, Marge, in a parody of the movie ''[[Indecent Proposal]]''.
Line 42: Line 39:
==Blue-Haired Lawyer==
==Blue-Haired Lawyer==
â
[[Image:blue-haired lawyer.jpg|left|150px|thumb|Blue-Haired Lawyer (right) consulting with Mr. Burns]]
 
The '''Blue-Haired Lawyer''', voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]], is Springfield's most prominent [[lawyer]] known for his pasty face (he is sometimes called the âpasty faced lawyerâ{{citation}}), blue hair, and nasal [[New York]] accent. He also occasionally appears to serve as a prosecutor. In one episode, he worked for Luvum & Burnham. Unlike [[Lionel Hutz]] or [[Gil Gunderson|Gil]], âBlue-Hairâ is a competent and accredited, though not necessarily ethical, lawyer. He has served as [[Montgomery Burns|Burnsâ]] head lawyer, and is known to be Mr. Burnsâ best and most cunning lawyer, helping him out with threats of the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant|Power Plant]] closing down and of Burns losing his money. He is a member of the Springfield [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. His clients tend to be antagonists of the Simpsons but there have been exceptions, such as Bart hiring him to get himself emancipated. He apparently gets frustrated with [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] occasionally. Writers [[Al Jean]] and [[Mike Reiss]] have both stated on the DVD commentaries that the voice is based on [[McCarthyism|McCarthy-era]] lawyer [[Roy Cohn]], and animator [[Jim Reardon]] has said that he is designed to look like character actor [[Charles Lane (actor)|Charles Lane]].
The '''Blue-Haired Lawyer''', voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]], is Springfield's most prominent [[lawyer]] known for his pasty face (he is sometimes called the âpasty faced lawyerâ{{citation}}), blue hair, and nasal [[New York]] accent. He also occasionally appears to serve as a prosecutor. In one episode, he worked for Luvum & Burnham. Unlike [[Lionel Hutz]] or [[Gil Gunderson|Gil]], âBlue-Hairâ is a competent and accredited, though not necessarily ethical, lawyer. He has served as [[Montgomery Burns|Burnsâ]] head lawyer, and is known to be Mr. Burnsâ best and most cunning lawyer, helping him out with threats of the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant|Power Plant]] closing down and of Burns losing his money. He is a member of the Springfield [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. His clients tend to be antagonists of the Simpsons but there have been exceptions, such as Bart hiring him to get himself emancipated. He apparently gets frustrated with [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] occasionally. Writers [[Al Jean]] and [[Mike Reiss]] have both stated on the DVD commentaries that the voice is based on [[McCarthyism|McCarthy-era]] lawyer [[Roy Cohn]], and animator [[Jim Reardon]] has said that he is designed to look like character actor [[Charles Lane (actor)|Charles Lane]].
Line 51: Line 47:
==Cecil Terwilliger==
==Cecil Terwilliger==
â
[[Image:Cecil and Bob.png|200px|thumb|Cecil (right) and Bob]]
 
'''Cecil Terwilliger''' is the younger brother of [[Sideshow Bob]]. Cecil, voiced by [[David Hyde Pierce]], and Robert, voiced by [[Kelsey Grammer]], have a relationship similar to that of [[Niles Crane|Niles]] and [[Frasier Crane]],{{Fact|date=November 2007}} whom the actors played on the [[situation comedy|sitcom]] ''[[Frasier]]''. One of the throw-away jokes in Cecil's episode was a sly reference to Frasier: when Bart leapt upon Cecil's back and said "Guess who?", Cecil replied "[[Maris Crane|Maris]]?" -- the name of Niles's [[unseen character|never seen]], but oft-mentioned, wife.
'''Cecil Terwilliger''' is the younger brother of [[Sideshow Bob]]. Cecil, voiced by [[David Hyde Pierce]], and Robert, voiced by [[Kelsey Grammer]], have a relationship similar to that of [[Niles Crane|Niles]] and [[Frasier Crane]],{{Fact|date=November 2007}} whom the actors played on the [[situation comedy|sitcom]] ''[[Frasier]]''. One of the throw-away jokes in Cecil's episode was a sly reference to Frasier: when Bart leapt upon Cecil's back and said "Guess who?", Cecil replied "[[Maris Crane|Maris]]?" -- the name of Niles's [[unseen character|never seen]], but oft-mentioned, wife.
Line 59: Line 54:
==Charlie==
==Charlie==
â
[[Image:Charlie.gif|150px|left|thumb|Charlie]]'''Charles "Charlie" ''' is the Dangerous Emissions Supervisor of Sector 7-G of the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]]. He is one of [[Homer Simpson]]âs friends and was involved in the fake emergency exit incident in 1993. After informing Mr. Burns of the need for a real emergency exit as opposed to the one painted on the wall, he got sucked into a tube that took him to a room where he was forced to dance for cackling men in turbans. In his absence, [[List of one-time characters from The Simpsons#Mindy Simmons|Mindy Simmons]] briefly took his place, but got fired afterwards. His first appearance was in "[[Life on the Fast Lane]]", when after Homer leaves the table during lunch he says, "Domestic problem". He is occasionally seen in [[Moe's Tavern]] drinking. In "[[King-Size Homer]]" he was briefly disabled as stated by Lenny after Homer notices he is not at the plant. However, he is well and healthy at the end of the episode. He has a wife and two children, seen in [[Homer the Smithers]]. He has an office, as seen in a CCTV camera in [[Homer Goes To College]]. He tells Homer (while Homer is working for the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]) that he has a plan to [[revolution|overthrow the government]] because they are not making [[high-definition television|HDTV]] happen soon enough, and is promptly arrested for conspiracy. In "[[Homie the Clown]]" he, along with other employees, was set on fire due to Homer's negligence. Charlie has spoken in very few episodes, but has been seen in the background more. He is voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]], who said that he was "doing an imitation of [[Lenny Leonard|Lenny]]".<ref>DVD commentary; episode [[Homer at the Bat|8F13]]</ref>
+
'''Charles "Charlie" ''' is the Dangerous Emissions Supervisor of Sector 7-G of the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]]. He is one of [[Homer Simpson]]âs friends and was involved in the fake emergency exit incident in 1993. After informing Mr. Burns of the need for a real emergency exit as opposed to the one painted on the wall, he got sucked into a tube that took him to a room where he was forced to dance for cackling men in turbans. In his absence, [[List of one-time characters from The Simpsons#Mindy Simmons|Mindy Simmons]] briefly took his place, but got fired afterwards. His first appearance was in "[[Life on the Fast Lane]]", when after Homer leaves the table during lunch he says, "Domestic problem". He is occasionally seen in [[Moe's Tavern]] drinking. In "[[King-Size Homer]]" he was briefly disabled as stated by Lenny after Homer notices he is not at the plant. However, he is well and healthy at the end of the episode. He has a wife and two children, seen in [[Homer the Smithers]]. He has an office, as seen in a CCTV camera in [[Homer Goes To College]]. He tells Homer (while Homer is working for the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]) that he has a plan to [[revolution|overthrow the government]] because they are not making [[high-definition television|HDTV]] happen soon enough, and is promptly arrested for conspiracy. In "[[Homie the Clown]]" he, along with other employees, was set on fire due to Homer's negligence. Charlie has spoken in very few episodes, but has been seen in the background more. He is voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]], who said that he was "doing an imitation of [[Lenny Leonard|Lenny]]".<ref>DVD commentary; episode [[Homer at the Bat|8F13]]</ref>
==Coach Lugash==
==Coach Lugash==
Line 65: Line 60:
==Judge Constance Harm==
==Judge Constance Harm==
â
[[Image:Constance Harm.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Judge Constance Harm]]
 
Judge '''Constance Harm''' (voiced by [[Jane Kaczmarek]]) is a harsh, unforgiving disciplinarian. She enjoys creating cruel punishments for criminals in her court. She is a parody of television's stern, no-nonsense ''[[Judge Judy]]''. She has hinted, at one point, to having been born a boy.
Judge '''Constance Harm''' (voiced by [[Jane Kaczmarek]]) is a harsh, unforgiving disciplinarian. She enjoys creating cruel punishments for criminals in her court. She is a parody of television's stern, no-nonsense ''[[Judge Judy]]''. She has hinted, at one point, to having been born a boy.
Line 74: Line 68:
==Crazy Cat Lady==
==Crazy Cat Lady==
â
[[Image:Crazy Cat Lady.png|thumb||left|Eleanor Abernathy (Crazy Cat Lady)]]
 
'''Eleanor Abernathy''', known as the '''Crazy Cat Lady''' and voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]], is a woman with the appearance and behavior of a stereotypical [[mental illness|mentally ill]] person. She is an [[animal hoarding|animal hoarder]] and is always surrounded by a large number of [[cat]]s. In nearly every appearance she screams [[gibberish]] or throws live cats at passers-by. Kent Brockman revealed the Crazy Cat Ladyâs true name, Eleanor Abernathy, during an interview in the episode â[[See Homer Run]].â
'''Eleanor Abernathy''', known as the '''Crazy Cat Lady''' and voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]], is a woman with the appearance and behavior of a stereotypical [[mental illness|mentally ill]] person. She is an [[animal hoarding|animal hoarder]] and is always surrounded by a large number of [[cat]]s. In nearly every appearance she screams [[gibberish]] or throws live cats at passers-by. Kent Brockman revealed the Crazy Cat Ladyâs true name, Eleanor Abernathy, during an interview in the episode â[[See Homer Run]].â
Line 85: Line 78:
==Disco Stu==
==Disco Stu==
â
[[Image:The Simpsons-Disco Stu.png|thumb|100px|Disco Stu]]
 
'''Disco "Stu" Stuart''' is a [[disco]] aficionado and is usually featured wearing a [[rhinestone]]-encrusted [[leisure suit]].
'''Disco "Stu" Stuart''' is a [[disco]] aficionado and is usually featured wearing a [[rhinestone]]-encrusted [[leisure suit]].
Line 94: Line 86:
==Eddie and Lou==
==Eddie and Lou==
â
[[Image:SimpEddie and lou.jpg|right|thumb|Eddie (Left) and Lou (Right)]]
 
'''Eddie and Lou''' are police officers with the [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]] Police department. Neither of their surnames has ever been shown. In "[[The Frying Game]]", Lou says that they don't have surnames, much like [[Cher]].
'''Eddie and Lou''' are police officers with the [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]] Police department. Neither of their surnames has ever been shown. In "[[The Frying Game]]", Lou says that they don't have surnames, much like [[Cher]].
Line 103: Line 94:
==Gil Gunderson==
==Gil Gunderson==
â
[[Image:gil-gunderson-52872.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Gil]]
 
'''Gilbert "Gil" Gunderson''', sometimes referring to himself as '''Old Gil''', is voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]. Gil is based on [[Jack Lemmon]]'s portrayal of Shelley Levene in the film version of ''[[Glengarry Glen Ross (film)|Glengarry Glen Ross]]'': a nervous, middle-aged man with the inability to hold a steady job due to strings of misfortunes that tend to hit him at the worst times.<ref>{{cite video | people=Groening, Matt|year=2006|title=The Simpsons The Complete Eighth Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[The Twisted World of Marge Simpson]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref> Gil made his debut in the episode "[[Realty Bites]]", where he plays a hapless real estate agent much like Lemmon does in the film. Lemmon himself plays a similar part in "[[The Twisted World of Marge Simpson]]".
'''Gilbert "Gil" Gunderson''', sometimes referring to himself as '''Old Gil''', is voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]. Gil is based on [[Jack Lemmon]]'s portrayal of Shelley Levene in the film version of ''[[Glengarry Glen Ross (film)|Glengarry Glen Ross]]'': a nervous, middle-aged man with the inability to hold a steady job due to strings of misfortunes that tend to hit him at the worst times.<ref>{{cite video | people=Groening, Matt|year=2006|title=The Simpsons The Complete Eighth Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[The Twisted World of Marge Simpson]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref> Gil made his debut in the episode "[[Realty Bites]]", where he plays a hapless real estate agent much like Lemmon does in the film. Lemmon himself plays a similar part in "[[The Twisted World of Marge Simpson]]".
Line 116: Line 106:
==Helen Lovejoy==
==Helen Lovejoy==
â
[[Image:Helen Lovejoy.png|left|100px|thumb|Helen Lovejoy]]
 
'''Helen Lovejoy''', voiced by [[Maggie Roswell]] and [[Marcia Mitzman Gaven]] is [[Reverend Timothy Lovejoy|Rev. Timothy]]âs judgemental and gossipy wife, and the mother of [[List of Springfield Elementary School students#Jessica Lovejoy|Jessica Lovejoy]].
'''Helen Lovejoy''', voiced by [[Maggie Roswell]] and [[Marcia Mitzman Gaven]] is [[Reverend Timothy Lovejoy|Rev. Timothy]]âs judgemental and gossipy wife, and the mother of [[List of Springfield Elementary School students#Jessica Lovejoy|Jessica Lovejoy]].
Line 125: Line 114:
==Herman==
==Herman==
â
[[Image:Herman-simpsons.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Herman in the episode "[[Bart the General]]".]]
 
'''Herman''', voiced by [[Harry Shearer]], is the owner of '''Hermanâs Military Antiques'''. He dresses in [[Battle Dress Uniform|military fatigues]]. He has only one arm; he claims to Bart that the other arm was lost by sticking it out of the window of a moving bus, although the writers had originally intended for him to give a different reason each time he appeared. His voice is similar to that of [[George H. W. Bush]], and he is based on Simpsons writer [[John Swartzwelder]]. A brilliant military tactician, Herman was instrumental in Bartâs victory in water balloon combat against Nelson and in the negotiation of the peace treaty between the two combatants in "[[Bart the General]]".
'''Herman''', voiced by [[Harry Shearer]], is the owner of '''Hermanâs Military Antiques'''. He dresses in [[Battle Dress Uniform|military fatigues]]. He has only one arm; he claims to Bart that the other arm was lost by sticking it out of the window of a moving bus, although the writers had originally intended for him to give a different reason each time he appeared. His voice is similar to that of [[George H. W. Bush]], and he is based on Simpsons writer [[John Swartzwelder]]. A brilliant military tactician, Herman was instrumental in Bartâs victory in water balloon combat against Nelson and in the negotiation of the peace treaty between the two combatants in "[[Bart the General]]".
Line 135: Line 123:
==Rabbi Hyman Krustofski==
==Rabbi Hyman Krustofski==
â
[[Image:Simpsons 8F05.png|200px|right|thumb|Hyman Krustofski ''(right)'' and [[Krusty the Clown|Krusty]] ''(left)'']]
 
'''[[Rabbi]] Hyman Krustofski''' (voiced by [[Jackie Mason]]) is the father of [[Krusty the Clown]]. His first appearance was in â[[Like Father, Like Clown]].â Krusty started to miss his long estranged father, who had abandoned him because Krusty wanted to become a Clown instead of a Rabbi. Bart and Lisa noticed this and did everything they could to convince the Rabbi to see his son, but he proved to be a stubborn man. They tried to beat him at his own game and quoted Jewish scripture that suggests he reunite with his son, however he easily countered this with Talmudic interpretation and alternate Bible verses. Lisa, out of ideas, suggests using a [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]] quote, which works and the Rabbi reunites with his son during the show. His second major appearance would be in â[[Today I Am a Clown]]â in which Krusty would decide to get a [[B'nai Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] and has to go to his father. In preparation, Krusty becomes a devout Jew and is later fired from his show. In a move of desperation, he decided to televise his Bar Mitzvah. It proved to be extremely successful, but was a disappointment to the Rabbi. In the end, Krusty decided to have a real Bar Mitzvah in a real [[synagogue|Shul]], which pleased his father. This would be the last appearance in which he was voiced by Jackie Mason. Jackie Mason voices the character in âLike Father, Like Clownâ and âToday I Am a Clown.â All other appearances are voiced by Dan Castellaneta. He would make a brief [[cameo appearance]] in â[[Homer's Triple Bypass|Homerâs Triple Bypass]],â and later in the episodes â[[Simpsons Christmas Stories]],â â[[Treehouse of Horror XVII]]â, and â[[On a Clear Day I Can't See My Sister]].â He also often appears in crowd shots.
'''[[Rabbi]] Hyman Krustofski''' (voiced by [[Jackie Mason]]) is the father of [[Krusty the Clown]]. His first appearance was in â[[Like Father, Like Clown]].â Krusty started to miss his long estranged father, who had abandoned him because Krusty wanted to become a Clown instead of a Rabbi. Bart and Lisa noticed this and did everything they could to convince the Rabbi to see his son, but he proved to be a stubborn man. They tried to beat him at his own game and quoted Jewish scripture that suggests he reunite with his son, however he easily countered this with Talmudic interpretation and alternate Bible verses. Lisa, out of ideas, suggests using a [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]] quote, which works and the Rabbi reunites with his son during the show. His second major appearance would be in â[[Today I Am a Clown]]â in which Krusty would decide to get a [[B'nai Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] and has to go to his father. In preparation, Krusty becomes a devout Jew and is later fired from his show. In a move of desperation, he decided to televise his Bar Mitzvah. It proved to be extremely successful, but was a disappointment to the Rabbi. In the end, Krusty decided to have a real Bar Mitzvah in a real [[synagogue|Shul]], which pleased his father. This would be the last appearance in which he was voiced by Jackie Mason. Jackie Mason voices the character in âLike Father, Like Clownâ and âToday I Am a Clown.â All other appearances are voiced by Dan Castellaneta. He would make a brief [[cameo appearance]] in â[[Homer's Triple Bypass|Homerâs Triple Bypass]],â and later in the episodes â[[Simpsons Christmas Stories]],â â[[Treehouse of Horror XVII]]â, and â[[On a Clear Day I Can't See My Sister]].â He also often appears in crowd shots.
Line 150: Line 137:
==Jebediah Springfield==
==Jebediah Springfield==
â
[[Image:JebSpr.jpg|thumb|150px|Jebediah's statue]]
 
'''Jebediah Obadiah Zachariah Jedediah Springfield''' is the purported historical founder of the [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|town of Springfield]]. Springfield had many famous quotations, such as âA noble spirit [[Culturally significant words and phrases from The Simpsons#Cromulent and embiggens|embiggens]] the smallest man,â and was well known for his [[silver]] tongue (literally; a metal [[prosthesis|prosthetic]] tongue, his original tongue having been bitten off by a [[Turkic peoples|Turkish]] pirate in a grog house fight). He also wears a [[coonskin cap]].
'''Jebediah Obadiah Zachariah Jedediah Springfield''' is the purported historical founder of the [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|town of Springfield]]. Springfield had many famous quotations, such as âA noble spirit [[Culturally significant words and phrases from The Simpsons#Cromulent and embiggens|embiggens]] the smallest man,â and was well known for his [[silver]] tongue (literally; a metal [[prosthesis|prosthetic]] tongue, his original tongue having been bitten off by a [[Turkic peoples|Turkish]] pirate in a grog house fight). He also wears a [[coonskin cap]].
Line 160: Line 146:
==Lindsey Naegle==
==Lindsey Naegle==
â
[[Image:Lindsey Naegle.PNG|thumb|left|200px|Lindsey Naegle]]
 
'''Lindsey Naegle''' (voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]]) first appeared in the episode "[[The Itchy & Scratchy & Poochie Show]]." In this episode her character was simply referred to as âFemale Network Executive,â and had brunette hair instead of her usual blonde. She later returned in "[[Girly Edition]]," still working with [[Krusty the Clown]]. Finally, in "[[They Saved Lisa's Brain|They Saved Lisaâs Brain]]," she was introduced as Lindsey Naegle, a member of the Springfield [[Mensa International|Mensa]] Society and head of Advanced Capital Ventures, specializing in [[synergy]] and books on how to cheat at [[Contract bridge|bridge]].
'''Lindsey Naegle''' (voiced by [[Tress MacNeille]]) first appeared in the episode "[[The Itchy & Scratchy & Poochie Show]]." In this episode her character was simply referred to as âFemale Network Executive,â and had brunette hair instead of her usual blonde. She later returned in "[[Girly Edition]]," still working with [[Krusty the Clown]]. Finally, in "[[They Saved Lisa's Brain|They Saved Lisaâs Brain]]," she was introduced as Lindsey Naegle, a member of the Springfield [[Mensa International|Mensa]] Society and head of Advanced Capital Ventures, specializing in [[synergy]] and books on how to cheat at [[Contract bridge|bridge]].
Line 171: Line 156:
==Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon==
==Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon==
â
[[Image:The Simpsons 5F04.png|200px|right|thumb|Manjula with Apu]]
 
'''Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon (nee Manjula Jamshed)''' (voiced by [[Jan Hooks]], [[Tress MacNeille]] in â[[The Sweetest Apu]]â) is [[Apu Nahasapeemapetilon|Apu]]âs wife and mother of their [[multiple birth|octuplets]]. She was [[Arranged marriage|arranged to be married]] to Apu when she was eight (as depicted in [[The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons]]) and Apu was to set out to [[United States|America]] for college (as depicted in â[[Much Apu About Nothing]]â). She also works at the [[Kwik-E-Mart]]. She claims that ''Fried Green Tomatoes'' is her favorite [[Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe|book]], [[Fried Green Tomatoes (film)|movie]], and [[fried green tomatoes (food)|food]]. She has excellent culinary abilities, demonstrated by her ability to make a wide variety of dishes using only chickpeas, lentils, and rice.
'''Manjula Nahasapeemapetilon (nee Manjula Jamshed)''' (voiced by [[Jan Hooks]], [[Tress MacNeille]] in â[[The Sweetest Apu]]â) is [[Apu Nahasapeemapetilon|Apu]]âs wife and mother of their [[multiple birth|octuplets]]. She was [[Arranged marriage|arranged to be married]] to Apu when she was eight (as depicted in [[The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons]]) and Apu was to set out to [[United States|America]] for college (as depicted in â[[Much Apu About Nothing]]â). She also works at the [[Kwik-E-Mart]]. She claims that ''Fried Green Tomatoes'' is her favorite [[Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe|book]], [[Fried Green Tomatoes (film)|movie]], and [[fried green tomatoes (food)|food]]. She has excellent culinary abilities, demonstrated by her ability to make a wide variety of dishes using only chickpeas, lentils, and rice.
Line 178: Line 162:
==Marvin Monroe==
==Marvin Monroe==
â
[[Image:Marvin Monroe.jpg|125px|right|thumb]]
 
'''Dr Marvin Monroe''' (voiced by [[Harry Shearer]]) is a local [[psychiatrist]] who was once [[Montgomery Burns|Mr Burns]]â therapist. He debuted in the first season's "[[There's No Disgrace Like Home]]," though he also appears in an episode made earlier but aired later, "[[Some Enchanted Evening (The Simpsons episode)|Some Enchanted Evening]]". Monroe promoted some [[subliminal message|subliminal]] weight-loss audio cassettes, and wrote books such as ''Iâm OK, So Why Aren't You?''. (A plot conceived for him in the early years and confirmed by [[Matt Groening]]<ref>DVD commentary; episode [[Some Enchanted Evening (The Simpsons episode)|7G01]]</ref> was never actually used.) References to his death began to appear in the series, such as the Marvin Monroe Memorial Hospital in "[[Who Shot Mr. Burns? (Part One)]]" and a mention of his death in the [[The Simpsons 138th Episode Spectacular|138th episode retrospective]]; there are also glimpses of both his grave (in [[Alone Again, Natura-Diddily]]) and a school gym named after him. However, he appeared briefly in the season 15 episode "[[Diatribe of a Mad Housewife]]" claiming to have been very sick. (The creators put the doctor on that ten-year-long hiatus because voicing Monroe hurt Shearer's throat.)
'''Dr Marvin Monroe''' (voiced by [[Harry Shearer]]) is a local [[psychiatrist]] who was once [[Montgomery Burns|Mr Burns]]â therapist. He debuted in the first season's "[[There's No Disgrace Like Home]]," though he also appears in an episode made earlier but aired later, "[[Some Enchanted Evening (The Simpsons episode)|Some Enchanted Evening]]". Monroe promoted some [[subliminal message|subliminal]] weight-loss audio cassettes, and wrote books such as ''Iâm OK, So Why Aren't You?''. (A plot conceived for him in the early years and confirmed by [[Matt Groening]]<ref>DVD commentary; episode [[Some Enchanted Evening (The Simpsons episode)|7G01]]</ref> was never actually used.) References to his death began to appear in the series, such as the Marvin Monroe Memorial Hospital in "[[Who Shot Mr. Burns? (Part One)]]" and a mention of his death in the [[The Simpsons 138th Episode Spectacular|138th episode retrospective]]; there are also glimpses of both his grave (in [[Alone Again, Natura-Diddily]]) and a school gym named after him. However, he appeared briefly in the season 15 episode "[[Diatribe of a Mad Housewife]]" claiming to have been very sick. (The creators put the doctor on that ten-year-long hiatus because voicing Monroe hurt Shearer's throat.)
Line 217: Line 200:
==Old Jewish Man==
==Old Jewish Man==
â
[[Image:crazy old man.gif|thumb|100px|The old Jewish man]]
 
The '''Old Jewish Man''', (sometimes called the '''Crazy Guy''' or '''Crazy Old Man''') is [[Abraham Simpson|Grampa Simpson]] and [[List of recurring characters from The Simpsons#Jasper Beardly|Jasper Beardley]]'s friend. Mayor Quimby once referred to him as "Old Jewish Man"; as well, a list of heart recipients listed him as "Old Jewish Man" ("[[Homer's Paternity Coot]]")
The '''Old Jewish Man''', (sometimes called the '''Crazy Guy''' or '''Crazy Old Man''') is [[Abraham Simpson|Grampa Simpson]] and [[List of recurring characters from The Simpsons#Jasper Beardly|Jasper Beardley]]'s friend. Mayor Quimby once referred to him as "Old Jewish Man"; as well, a list of heart recipients listed him as "Old Jewish Man" ("[[Homer's Paternity Coot]]")
Line 231: Line 213:
== Rich Texan== <!-- This section is linked from [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]] -->
== Rich Texan== <!-- This section is linked from [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]] -->
â
[[Image:ColonelO'Hara.jpg|thumb|180px|Rich Texan]]
+
'''Rich Texan''' (both name and description), voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]], is a stereotypical rich, callous but gregarious business owner. He is very similar to the character of Mr Judson on the [[Burns and Allen]] radio show of the 1940s. He is an active member of the Springfield [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and speaks with a heavy Texan drawl. In the fifth season episode â[[$pringfield (Or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Legalized Gambling)|$pringfield]]â (his debut), Homer addresses the Rich Texan as [[United States Senate|Senator]], although this was never again referenced. Rich Texan sports a [[bolo tie]] and a white cowboy hat. He is also obsessive-compulsive, as revealed in â[[The Seemingly Never-Ending Story]].â He has stated he enjoys moonlight walks on the beach; in the same [[Marge's Son Poisoning|episode]] he held Homer and Moe at gunpoint while forcing them to walk along with him after being conned by the two. He is well known for pulling out a pair of revolvers and firing them into the air while yelling "Yee Haw!" whenever he is happy or excited, and once in "[[Pray Anything]]" he went over the top and lost his mind after doing something generous to [[Ned Flanders]]. He has been to jail at least once when one of his stray bullets hit a Texas Ranger. The police made him switch to blanks, but he noted that "They just don't feel the same". He has a [[gay]] grandson, as revealed in "[[Million Dollar Abie]]", a possible reference to US Vice President [[Dick Cheney]]'s homosexual daughter. He has a daughter named Paris Texan, a play on [[Paris Hilton]] and [[Paris, Texas]]. In "[[Midnight Towboy]]", he revealed he suffers from pogonophobia (the fear of beards and moustaches); he then promptly shoots a man dressed as [[Santa Claus]]. In the episode [[Revenge is a Dish Best Served Three Times]], it is revealed that he is from [[Connecticut]]. This may be a possible reference to [[George W. Bush|George Bush]] as he was also born in Connecticut, but acts as though he was born and raised in Texas.

Line 242: Line 224:
==Judge Roy Snyder==
==Judge Roy Snyder==
â
[[Image:JudgeRoySnider.jpg|thumb|200px|Judge Roy Snyder]]
 
'''Judge Roy Snyder''', voiced by [[Harry Shearer]], is a [[judge]] in [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]]. He is one of the main African-American characters in The Simpsons. Starting off as stern and no-nonsense (with a grudge against [[Lionel Hutz]] for running over his son repeatedly), Snyder later became known for his lenient punishments. Judge Snyder also bears a resemblance to Judge [[Robert Bork]] as well as Judge [[Joe Brown (judge)|Joe Brown]]. In earlier episodes he has yellow skin; in ''[[Bart Gets Hit by a Car]]'' his name is Moulton; his usual name may be an allusion to [[Roy Bean|Judge Roy Bean]].
'''Judge Roy Snyder''', voiced by [[Harry Shearer]], is a [[judge]] in [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]]. He is one of the main African-American characters in The Simpsons. Starting off as stern and no-nonsense (with a grudge against [[Lionel Hutz]] for running over his son repeatedly), Snyder later became known for his lenient punishments. Judge Snyder also bears a resemblance to Judge [[Robert Bork]] as well as Judge [[Joe Brown (judge)|Joe Brown]]. In earlier episodes he has yellow skin; in ''[[Bart Gets Hit by a Car]]'' his name is Moulton; his usual name may be an allusion to [[Roy Bean|Judge Roy Bean]].
Line 250: Line 231:
==Ruth Powers==
==Ruth Powers==
â
[[Image:RuthPowers.jpg|thumb|Ruth Powers]]
 
'''Ruth Powers''' is [[Simpson family|the Simpsons]]' next-door neighbor, introduced when she moves to their neighborhood in the episode â[[New Kid on the Block]].â She is divorced and has a daughter, Laura Powers, who no longer lives with her. She is usually seen as a background character, sometimes in events that occurred even before she moved next door (such as the baby shower for Maggie in "And Maggie Makes Three"). She even continues to be a background character despite her later imprisonment. She nearly always wears a red headscarf. In the episode "[[The Cartridge Family]]" she was part of the NRA. She was voiced by [[Pamela Reed]] in her first two speaking appearances.
'''Ruth Powers''' is [[Simpson family|the Simpsons]]' next-door neighbor, introduced when she moves to their neighborhood in the episode â[[New Kid on the Block]].â She is divorced and has a daughter, Laura Powers, who no longer lives with her. She is usually seen as a background character, sometimes in events that occurred even before she moved next door (such as the baby shower for Maggie in "And Maggie Makes Three"). She even continues to be a background character despite her later imprisonment. She nearly always wears a red headscarf. In the episode "[[The Cartridge Family]]" she was part of the NRA. She was voiced by [[Pamela Reed]] in her first two speaking appearances.
Line 277: Line 257:
==Sea Captain==
==Sea Captain==
â
[[Image:Captain3.gif|thumb|left|200 px|The Sea Captain]]
 
'''Horatio McCallister''', also known as '''The Sea Captain''' is a sea captain (voice of [[Hank Azaria]]) with a [[West Country dialects|West Country accent]]. On several occasions, he acknowledges his incompetence with a depressed: "Yarr, I don't know what I'm doin'." He is a member of the Springfield [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] and has a literal "wooden leg" in which he keeps liquor. In "[[Bart of War]]" he uses his wooden leg to have a vicious sword fight with [[List of celebrities in The Simpsons#Sideshow Mel|Sideshow Mel]]'s bone.
'''Horatio McCallister''', also known as '''The Sea Captain''' is a sea captain (voice of [[Hank Azaria]]) with a [[West Country dialects|West Country accent]]. On several occasions, he acknowledges his incompetence with a depressed: "Yarr, I don't know what I'm doin'." He is a member of the Springfield [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] and has a literal "wooden leg" in which he keeps liquor. In "[[Bart of War]]" he uses his wooden leg to have a vicious sword fight with [[List of celebrities in The Simpsons#Sideshow Mel|Sideshow Mel]]'s bone.
Line 284: Line 263:
==Squeaky Voiced Teen==
==Squeaky Voiced Teen==
â
[[Image:Squeaky Voiced Teen.png|thumb|left|200px|Squeaky Voiced Teen]]
 
'''Squeaky Voiced Teen''', also known as '''Jeremy Freedman''', (voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]) is one of few [[adolescence|teenagers]] on the show and is perpetually trapped in a series of dead-end jobs. He is also referred to as "'''Pimple-faced teen'''", "Pimple-faced kid", "Puberty Boy", "Geeky Teenager", and, on one occasion, "Old Man Peterson". The squeaky-voiced teen has [[acne vulgaris]], and his voice is in the process of breaking.
'''Squeaky Voiced Teen''', also known as '''Jeremy Freedman''', (voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]) is one of few [[adolescence|teenagers]] on the show and is perpetually trapped in a series of dead-end jobs. He is also referred to as "'''Pimple-faced teen'''", "Pimple-faced kid", "Puberty Boy", "Geeky Teenager", and, on one occasion, "Old Man Peterson". The squeaky-voiced teen has [[acne vulgaris]], and his voice is in the process of breaking.
Line 296: Line 274:
==Wiseguy==<!-- This section is linked from [[List of characters in The Simpsons]] -->
==Wiseguy==<!-- This section is linked from [[List of characters in The Simpsons]] -->
â
[[Image:Wiseguy.gif|thumb|125px|Wiseguy]]
 
'''Wiseguy''' (also commonly known as the '''Sarcastic Clerk''', '''Raphael''', or '''middle-aged man'''), voiced by [[Hank Azaria]], is a man with a [[sarcasm|sarcastic]] outlook on life. He has held numerous jobs in Springfield including: garage owner, mail man, [[Taxicab|taxi]] driver, gun salesman, and various shop clerks and handymen. He has an apparent dislike to [[Comic Book Guy]], presumably because both of them are the most sarcastic characters on the show. However, his most-occurring job is a [[Repossession|repo-man]], of which (when he "accidentally" hurts [[Milhouse Van Houten|Milhouse]]) he says âHa ha! I love this job!â (in â[[The President Wore Pearls]]â). He is usually seen as a balding [[smoking|smoker]] with gray hair and a gray [[moustache]]. His voice is intended to resemble [[Charles Bronson]], as seen when the Simpsons try to travel to [[Branson, Missouri|Branson]], [[Missouri]], but mistakenly end up in Bronson, Missouri first. He often calls people âpallie,â or âboyo". In â[[Day of the Jackanapes]]â, [[Sideshow Bob]] identifies his first name as '''Raphael'''.
'''Wiseguy''' (also commonly known as the '''Sarcastic Clerk''', '''Raphael''', or '''middle-aged man'''), voiced by [[Hank Azaria]], is a man with a [[sarcasm|sarcastic]] outlook on life. However, his most-occurring job is a [[Repossession|repo-man]], of which (when he "accidentally" hurts [[Milhouse Van Houten|Milhouse]]) he says âHa ha! I love this job!â (in â[[The President Wore Pearls]]â). He is usually seen as a balding [[smoking|smoker]] with gray hair and a gray [[moustache]]. His voice is intended to resemble [[Charles Bronson]], as seen when the Simpsons try to travel to [[Branson, Missouri|Branson]], [[Missouri]], but mistakenly end up in Bronson, Missouri first. He often calls people âpallie,â or âboyo". In â[[Day of the Jackanapes]]â, [[Sideshow Bob]] identifies his first name as '''Raphael'''.
==Yes Guy==
==Yes Guy==
â
[[Image:yes guy.png|thumb|left|120px|The Yes Guy]]
 
The '''Yes Guy''' (also known as '''The [[Frank Nelson]] Type'''<ref>Groenig, Matt and McCann, Jesse L.: ''The SimpsonsâOne Step Beyond Forever'', page 54.</ref>; Homer refers to him as "That jerk who always goes 'Yeeeeees?'") is a character known for bellowing âYe-e-e-es?!â in a rising inflection, and appears to be highly eccentric in both his speech and appearance, voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]. During his first appearance, in â[[Mayored to the Mob]],â Homer asks âWhy do you talk like that?â; Yes-Guyâs response was âI had a strooooooke!â He also made an appearance in [[Homer vs. Dignity]] of [[The Simpsons (season 12)|Season Twelve]]. During "[[The Great Louse Detective]]", he enjoys [[Marge Simpson]]'s hair rubbing upon his buttocks. He is often seen working at Costington's department store, in which both he and Costington are apparently on good terms with. He is juror number twelve of the Springfield Panel of Jury ("[[The Monkey Suit]]").
The '''Yes Guy''' (also known as '''The [[Frank Nelson]] Type'''<ref>Groenig, Matt and McCann, Jesse L.: ''The SimpsonsâOne Step Beyond Forever'', page 54.</ref>; Homer refers to him as "That jerk who always goes 'Yeeeeees?'") is a character known for bellowing âYe-e-e-es?!â in a rising inflection, and appears to be highly eccentric in both his speech and appearance, voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]. During his first appearance, in â[[Mayored to the Mob]],â Homer asks âWhy do you talk like that?â; Yes-Guyâs response was âI had a strooooooke!â He also made an appearance in [[Homer vs. Dignity]] of [[The Simpsons (season 12)|Season Twelve]]. During "[[The Great Louse Detective]]", he enjoys [[Marge Simpson]]'s hair rubbing upon his buttocks. He is often seen working at Costington's department store, in which both he and Costington are apparently on good terms with. He is juror number twelve of the Springfield Panel of Jury ("[[The Monkey Suit]]").
